facts.text: A proceeding was instituted against the appellant, Bibhuti Bhusan Chatterjee, under s. 107 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the Court of the Magistrate of First Class at Bhagalpur.
The learned magistrate directed the appellant to execute a bond of Rs. 5,000 with two sureties of the like amount each to keep the peace for a period of one year.
The appellant challenged this order by his appeal before the Additional Session Judge at Bhagalpur.
The appellate judge agreed with the decision of the learned magistrate and the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed.
The appellant took the matter before the High Court at Patna by his Criminal Revision Application No. 924 of 1957.
Certified copies of the orders passed by the two courts below were filed by the appellant along with his revisional application without any court fees.
The appellant was called upon to pay court fee of Rs. 52.75 and Rs. 50.75 nP. on the two orders respectively.
The High Court took the view that the report made by the stamp reporter was consistent with the practice which the High Court had followed and the said practice was fully justified by Art. 9.
The contention raised by the appellant that no stamp need be affixed to the two orders was rejected and he was directed to affix the necessary stamps within two weeks.
The appellant applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution that the case was fit for appeal to this Court.
This appeal is being fought as a test case in order to test the validity of the relevant practice prevailing in the Patna High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether certified copies of orders passed in criminal proceedings under s.107 CrPC require payment of court fees under Art.9 Sch.I of Court Fees Act VII of 1870 when filed in revisional application before High Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: In construing Art.9 it would be relevant to bear in mind the policy which Legislature has deliberately adopted in enacting the material provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure dealing with supplying copies to accused free of cost (citing ss.173(4), 207A(3), 210(2), 251A(1), 317(1), proviso to 548 CrPC).
Provisions of Court Fees Act should be strictly construed in favour of the litigant and no document should be held chargeable unless clearly falls within the provisions.
Court fee under Art.9 may sometimes work hardship on accused persons.

respondent_arguments.text: The report of stamp reporter consistent with practice followed by High Court justified by Art.9.

court_reasoning.text: Policy of CrPC irrelevant for construing Court Fees Act; s.4 mandates fee for any document specified in Schedules filed in court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question decided solely by reference to Court Fees Act provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Principle of liberal construction inapplicable unless Art.9 capable of two constructions; words clear and unambiguous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.9 covers copy of any judicial proceeding or order not otherwise provided for, including from criminal courts.

court_reasoning.text: Order in criminal proceeding is judicial proceeding under s.4(m) CrPC; copies of such orders filed in High Court attract Art.9.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Copies of criminal judgments or orders must bear court fee under Art.9.

court_reasoning.text: View consistent with Patna HC practice and Travancore-Cochin HC decision; Legislature may consider exemption as in Madras.

holdings.text: Certified copies of criminal orders/judgments filed in High Court require court fee stamp under Art.9 Sch.I Court Fees Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: On construing taxing provisions: when intention clear, equity irrelevant.

precedents_cited.case_name: James Paul Alexander v. James Arthur Edwards
precedents_cited.relevance: Same view on construction of corresponding Art.10 Court Fees Act.

statutes_cited.name: Court Fees Act VII of 1870
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandates fees for documents filed; Art.9 applies to copies of judicial proceedings/orders from criminal courts.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings under s.107; policy of free copies to accused noted but irrelevant; judicial proceeding defined.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Patna High Court's view and practice requiring court fees under Art.9 on certified copies of criminal orders filed in revision, rejecting appellant's contentions.

key_quotes.text: "every document which falls within the purview of s. 4 must bear the court fee prescribed by the relevant provision"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes mandatory nature of court fees under Court Fees Act.

key_quotes.text: "the words used in Art. 9 are clear and unambiguous, and ... lead only to one conclusion"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is thus obvious that every document which falls within the purview of s. 4 must bear the court fee"
